101.description: In the last 2 years, I mastered the art of cracking the coding and system design interviews and landed on multiple offers from FAANG companies. During this time, I collected useful tips and tricks to make the proccess easier and more fun.   During the workshop, I will present a sample system design intreview question and walk through a solution which can easily impress interviewers. I will share with my intrerview experience with Facebook, Amazon, Bloomberg and resources to prepare for them.
101.title: Workshop: Cracking the System Desing Interview

102.description: Every coroutine needs a Job. Surprisingly, this is what forms their relationship with their children. Not an easy relationship - it involves inheritance, awaiting, cancellation, and exception handling. Even though those mechanisms might seem scary and complicated, they are actually really intuitive and reasonable once we see them from the right perspective. Letďż˝s do that, and on the way, letďż˝s have some fun.
102.title: Lecture: Parents cancelling their children - hard relationship between Kotlin coroutines

103.description: We'll talk about technics and methods of debugging frontend code, frequently encountered bugs in frontend development, time-saver tips and suggestion for debugging.
103.title: Lecture: Debugging Frontend Applications

104.description: The Internet is an awesome place where everyone can find interesting materials for them. Unfortunately, sometimes we forget some people cannot use it the same way as most of us - e.g. people with vision, motion, or cognitive disabilities. Why is accessibility so unpopular among developers? I believe it's not because of bad will - we often don't understand our users' problems. It's why I want to show some tricks to better understand users with disabilities, talk about the most popular mistakes (and fixes for them), and improvements you can include in your development process to avoid accessibility problems in the future.
104.title: Lecture: How to make the Internet accessible for everyone

105.description: The Kotlin type system is amazingly designed. It was designed and constantly improved for years, and it was built based on experiences from other typing systems. As a result, it gives us very comfortable nullability support, type inference, universal guards, and much more. In this presentation, weďż˝ll dive deep into Kotlin typing systems and how small design choices lead to a better programming experience.
105.title: The beauty of the Kotlin type system

106.description: IaaC is very popular in mid-sized and big enterprises. I am going to show you how easy is to create full CI/CD process for creating infrastructure in GCP using Terraform.
106.title: Lecture: Why Infrastructure as a Code (IaaC) is so cool?

107.description: This short story is about why we should go with Angular Framework and what it gives us.
107.title: Lecture: Angular - why to code

108.description: In this talk we'll review how to use Platform Views on Android and iOS. What are the most surprising considerations when working with them? What if some native library does not support Flutter and you need to display its UI in the app? We'll look into showing native views on desktop platforms and see what is still missing in this area.
108.title: Lecture: Native Platform Views in Flutter for Mobile and Beyond

109.description: In this talk, we are going to see how can we use BigQuery ML and VertexAI Pipelines to create robust, trackable and reusable Machine Learning pipelines.  Additionally, we are going to review how to deploy Pipelines to Artifact Registry as part of CD process and trigger them easily directly from our Cloud environment.
109.title: Lecture: Using BigQuery ML in Vertex AI Pipelines: easy and robust MLOps

110.description: 1.First designers in the world. First visual communication examples in the history Egypt art history Visual communication today  2.What is User Experience Position of the human in the user experience Position of the problems in the user experience Combination of the human and problem  3.User experience 30 000 years ago World first technologies User experience in world-first technologies  4.User Experience in our daily life TV remotes Shopping malls and public transportation  5.Famous brands and experience marketing What is experience marketing?  6.Experience marketing strategy of McDonaldďż˝s Golden standart of McDonaldďż˝s Gaining new clients for the future  7.My experience about UX design in a digital product Micro changes and big results
110.title: Lecture: User Experience Design in Our Daily Life

111.description: This talk outlines how to implement Modern Android Architecture to build scalable, flexible and testable apps. You'll learn about different architecture layers, their scope and how they communicate with each other. You'll see how the data is produced and transformed into UI state using Unidirectional Data Flow (UDF). And finally, we'll discuss how you can leverage modularization to take your codebase to the next level.
111.title: Lecture: Modern Android Architecture

112.description: Hi there! This talk gonna be about How To Bootstrap your Cloud Infrastructure, get away from routine tasks and just... code. I bet we are all familiar with tfw you need setup typical Cloud Architecture for a pet/client project and just notice how much time is wasted on stuff you've already done about  1000 times before?  So am I. I asked myself if it's really necessary Of course not. In this session, we will talk through useful tools, tips&tricks and open-source projects that will simplify your life. Furthermore, I will show you how to set up your own Cloud Accelerator with Terraform and some magic. And as a cherry on top: how to personalize Accelerator for your specific needs! As simple as 1, 2, 3.
112.title: Lecture: Get Rid Of Routine Tasks in Cloud in 1, 2, 3...

113.description: While building contained apps is relatively predictable in terms of complexity, building apps that interface with peripherals and IoT introduces a number of complexities which are often times overlooked by engineers. I'll walk you through a few of these and tell you how to properly mitigate them.
113.title: Lecture: Nonobvious complexities when building technology at the intersection of physical and digital worlds

114.description: You have a vision of a revolutionary feature that will push the business forward, attract more users, and make it the next Unicorn. Once you're ready to act on your ideas, a product manager approaches you with a specification for some other feature - develop it. Sounds familiar? You feel the drive to make an impact. You want to be heard - not just follow the herd. Yonatan will share the lessons on Impact Driven Development that he learned while working with startups and building various teams. How to channel your creativity, passion, and strong will to make a change. How to transform the way you develop and bring your ideas to life.
114.title: Lecture: How to become a developer that everyone wants in their team?

115.description: I would like to demonstrate wide capabilities of our MongoDB document model database - offered as managed service on all clouds with functionalities to address use-cases for full text search search, data archive, offline scenarios on mobile and end-to-end IoT.
115.title: Lecture: How to boost your app with MongoDB Atlas on Google Cloud?

116.description: This talk will go deep on what to take into account when deciding if your current mobile app requires a major rewrite, polish, or starting from scratch. This topic can be an endless discussion so I try to be straight to the point and base suggestions on my own experience. In the end, this should give you a better understanding what are tradeoffs and how you can prepare for them, but still, there is no one perfect answer for all projects out there.   Talk won't go into specific technical details but will touch on them and focus more on business/organization side and what advantages and disadvantages you can expect based on key decisions. Where to spend more time and where to push for `good enough` approach.
116.title: Lecture: To rewrite or refactor the mobile app?

117.description: I will talk about integrating many points of view (Development, Design, Project Management, Cloud, external Marketing Agencies, Client, GDPR and others.) in such way that nothing explodes and the final projects have the highest possible quality.
117.title: Lecture: The impossible task of combining many external processes

118.description: You have no idea how to start creating your own website or how to code at all? Perfect! Please join me at my workshop to gain some knowledge: - how to write some stuff using HTML and CSS (with a helping hand of Boostrap), - how the components are built (via Material Design) and - where to host it (with free Firebase Hosting).  This is a BYOD workshop, so please Bring Your Own Device - Windows/macOS/Linux - if it's working it will be fine!  There will be also a polish-only workshop, so if you think that you could have any issues understanding english, please register to other workshop.
118.title: Workshop: Websites creation 101 with Firebase hosting, Material Design and Twitter Bootstrap (BYOD)

119.description: Nie masz pojęcia, jak zacząć tworzyć własną stronę internetową lub jak w ogóle kodować? idealny! Zapraszam na moje warsztaty w celu zdobycia wiedzy: - jak napisać kilka rzeczy w HTML i CSS (z Boostrapem), - jak zbudowane są komponenty (poprzez Material Design) i - gdzie go hostować (z Free Firebase Hosting).  To warsztaty BYOD, więc przynieś własne urządzenie - Windows/macOS/Linux - jeśli działa, wszystko będzie dobrze!  Odbędą się również warsztaty tylko w języku angielskim, więc jeśli uważasz, że możesz mieć problem ze zrozumieniem języka polskiego, zarejestruj się proszę na drugi warsztat.
119.title: Workshop: Podstawy tworzenia stron internetowych z Firebase Hosting, Material Design i Twitter Bootstrap (BYOD)

120.description: Do you know that Poland is full of different tech-related communities? Let's create a common space to cooperate and organize fantastic events together!
120.title: Workshop: Building the next ecosystem of communities - together

121.description: At some moment in our career, we would might question ourselves “should I become a Lead or Manager?“. Often we don’t have a clear answer to that, and we end up taking the decision based on not clear assumptions. Let’s discuss team leadership and management to understand how this role can directly impact the success of a team, and highlight topics you might pay attention to when transitioning from IC to an effective Engineering Manager
121.title: Lecture: The software engineer journey: From IC to engineering manager

122.description: During our speech we will describe how data pipelines are built from various perspectives. We will show the difference between the Data Scientist's tasks and how they differ from Data Engineer's work. Do they exclude each other or rather they are complementary? What is the symbiosis between Cloud Composer and Google Vertex AI?
122.title: Lecture: Data Scientist meets Data Engineer

123.description: Evolution Of Cloud / Adaptation of CI-CD
123.title: Lecture: Evolution Of Cloud in IT Industry and CI-CD

1.description: Get your badge, coffee, enjoy talking with tech edicts around
1.title: Registration & morning coffee

3.description: Coffee and quizes on the 0 Floor
3.title: Coffee Break + Kahoots !!!

5.description: We invite everyone today to afterparty at  18.30. Password at the entrance DEVFEST. MultiPub Pod Grubą Kaśką, aleja Solidarności 68a, 00-240 Warszawa
5.title: After party

124.description: Angular is a full-fledged framework that provides a complete solution for building web applications, including tools for building the user interface, managing data, and implementing business logic. It uses a language called TypeScript, which is a superset of JavaScript that adds optional static typing and other features. This makes Angular well-suited for large, complex applications that require a lot of code and strong typing. The aim of this presentation is to introduce this unconventional tool and how it can be used intelligently.
124.title: Lecture: ANGULAR 15 - Developing applications with less code and less time

125.description: I've attended many hackathons all over the world and even managed to win a few of them. During my talk, I'll share some practical tips on how to efficiently build a mobile app and pitch it to the judges in less than 24h.
125.title: Lecture: How to build a mobile app in 24?

126.description:
A hands-on introduction for complete beginners to Artificial Intelligence GPT-3 offered by OpenAI.

Emphasis will be placed on showing the use cases and available options for the tool. The amount of theory will be minimized. Attendees will be encouraged to try to interact with GPT-3 tools.   David Chalmers, an Australian philosopher, described GPT-3 as ``one of the most interesting and important AI systems ever produced`` An April 2022 review in The New York Times described GPT-3's capabilities as being able to write original prose with fluency equivalent to that of a human.
126.title: Workshop: Intro to GPT-3: ``one of the most interesting and important AI systems ever produced`` - end quote

127.description: Let's learn the essential Kotlin Coroutines use cases and best practices: How to transform callbacks or blocking calls into suspend functions, how to create scope and how to work with suspend functions.
127.title: Workshop: Essentials of Kotlin Coroutines

129.description: A brief introduction about how to start the journey with Angular.
129.title: Workshop: Angular - how to code

130.description: When we set the upper limit of PC-DOS at 640K, we thought nobody would ever need that much memory. — William Gates, chairman of Microsoft.`` In our world, RAM is becoming cheaper and cheaper every day. Having a PC/Mac with 16GB RAM is no longer a big deal. How about the mobile world? We are bombarded every year with devices with amazing specs: a flagship device with 4 GB RAM, an 8 GB device, or even one with 16 GB. On a desktop it really makes a difference. Is it the same on a smartphone? Even with 8GB of RAM, why does my app still crash when it runs out of memory? During this talk, we will learn how Android memory management works, what SWAP, GC, Native Allocations and other technical terms are. Most importantly, you'll learn how to write a junk-free and out-of-memory application. This will not be a lecture on ``don't allocate memory when you don't need it,`` but rather lessons learned when developing monday.com's Android app
130.title: Lecture: 640K ought to be enough for anyone

131.description:
The so called ``Modern Data Stack`` is often explained as ever growing number of tools and frameworks that you have to use to build a modern data processing pipelines. While there are various attempts to make data pipelines more homogeneous and build your data needs around some ecosystems, the need to orchestrate your workflows is not going away - if anything, more and more of those pipelines depend on multiple tools in frameworks working together. And like an orchestra consisting of many instruments, they need to have an orchestrator - or a conductor for an orchestra - when playing together.
 
 Apache Airlfow is by far, the most popular workflow orchestrator in the world and its getting more and more relevant, especially that it becomes more than an orchestrator. Airflow 2 turned into modern Orchestration Platform. With Airflow 2.5 released just few days ago, cementing the ``Airflow being a Platform`` approach, you can do much more than **just** orchestration.
 
 This talk focuses on how you can leverage the new features of Airflow in fulfilling your Data Engineering needs.
131.title: Lecture: Modern Data Stack Pipelines with Airflow 2.5

132.description: You've already made the decision to become an Engineering Manager, whether it's a new company and a new team or a change of career direction at your current company. During the discussion, Nataliya & Rodolfo will share the learnings from challenges they faced in this transition, practical tips, and what motivated them not to give.
132.title: Discussion: Journey from IC to Engineering Manager

133.description:
Jump into MongoDB Atlas yourself and complete a series of exercises led by our team of solution architects, who will be there to support you and answer any questions. Exercises will include basic MQL CRUD operations, indexes and general index building guidelines, creating aggregation pipeline queries, and Search! Things that should be installed by participants: 

Install MongoDB Compass: https://www.mongodb.com/try/download/compass
133.title: Workshop: Create your first MongoDB Atlas cluster on Google Cloud [BYOD]

Azimjon__Pulatov.bio: I am a software engineer at Amazon, recently interned at Facebook and currently study at Polish-Japanese Academy. In my free time, I like to learn and share my knowledge about programming, distributed systems and soft skills. Also a part-time YouTuber :)
Azimjon__Pulatov.name: Azimjon Pulatov
Azimjon__Pulatov.title: Software Development Engineer

Marcin__Moskala.bio: Marcin Moskala is an experienced developer and Kotlin trainer. He is the founder of the Kt. Academy, an official JetBrains partner for Kotlin training, author of the books Effective Kotlin, Kotlin Coroutines, Functional Kotlin and Android Development with Kotlin. He is also the main author of the biggest medium publication about Kotlin and a speaker invited to many programming conferences.
Marcin__Moskala.name: Marcin Moskała
Marcin__Moskala.shortBio: Experienced developer, writer and Kotlin trainer.
Marcin__Moskala.title: Senior Developer

Diyorbek__Sadullaev.bio: I am a software developer with 4 years of professional experience in building web applications. My primary area of expertise is frontend development, particularly React JS and React Native applications. I also have experience building server-side applications in Node.js utilizing frameworks such as Express and Next.js. I usually work with the JavaScript/TypeScript ecosystem, however, I love coding in C++. I have created a few projects in C++ and some of them are hybrid Node.js applications that have lightning-fast core written in C++.
Diyorbek__Sadullaev.name: Diyorbek Sadullaev
Diyorbek__Sadullaev.shortBio: I am a frontend developer with 4 years of professional experience.
Diyorbek__Sadullaev.title: Frontend Developer

Dominika__Zajac.name: Dominika Zając
Dominika__Zajac.bio: Full-stack developer who loves sharing their knowledge and singing. Google Developer Expert for Web Technologies, software engineer at Qualtrics, public speaker, trainer and blogger. Talking and writing about Web, a11y, teaching others how to code and code best practices.
Dominika__Zajac.shortBio: Full-stack developer who loves sharing their knowledge and singing. Google Developer Expert for Web Technologies, software engineer at Qualtrics, public speaker, trainer and blogger. Talking and writing about Web, a11y, teaching others how to code and code best practices.
Dominika__Zajac.title: Software Engineer

Emil__Dabrowski.name: Emil Dabrowski
Emil__Dabrowski.bio: Twenty-eight years experience in IT. He worked with the best technologies, such as Microsoft, Sun, EMC, Citrix, CyberArk, IBM, and VMWare and last five years with GCP. He works with enterprises on movement to the GCP and architecting applications in the new environment. He focuses on infrastructure automation (Terraform) and containerization (Kubernetes). He has certificates for all used technologies: GCP x 8, Kubernetes x 8, and Terraform x 1. He is Google Cloud Authorized Trainer and Google Developer Expert (GCP).
Emil__Dabrowski.shortBio: Senior Cloud Architect in Devoteam G Cloud focused on Google Cloud Platform, infrastructure automation and security.
Emil__Dabrowski.title: Senior Cloud Architect

Jakub__Kolakowski.name: Jakub Kołakowski
Jakub__Kolakowski.bio:
Chapter Leader @ GDG Warsaw

Owner @ SandGroup

CTO @ SEVI

CTO @ alboalbo

Working in the IT since 2002, Web enthusiast, Fuckup manager.
Jakub__Kolakowski.shortBio: Do'er + Chapter Leader @ GDG Warsaw + Owner @ SandGroup + CTO @ SEVI + CTO @ alboalbo + Working in the IT since 2002, Web enthusiast, Fuckup manager.
Jakub__Kolakowski.title: Chapter Leader

Stanislaw__Smyl.name: Stanislaw Smyl
Stanislaw__Smyl.bio: Stanislaw is a Data Engineer with Data Science background working in a sport analytics field. He loves Google Cloud Platform, but GCP not always loves him back. Focused on writing efficient ETL/ELT processes, modern Data Warehousing tools and Machine Learning Operations, staying on top of what Google's Vertex AI has to offer.
Stanislaw__Smyl.shortBio: Stanislaw is a Data Engineer with Data Science background working in a sport analytics field. He loves Google Cloud Platform, but GCP not always loves him back. Focused on writing efficient ETL/ELT processes, modern Data Warehousing tools and Machine Learning Operations, staying on top of what Google's Vertex AI has to offer.
Stanislaw__Smyl.title: Data Engineer

Tomasz__Flis.name: Tomasz Flis
Tomasz__Flis.bio: I am passionate about programming, expanding my own abilities, and sharing knowledge. I try to be up to date with the latest versions of technology and I am happy to learn new, unknown solutions. I have been enjoying programming for a long time because it's doing something out of nothing.
Tomasz__Flis.shortBio: Passionate developer from Poland with a focus on Web technologies.
Tomasz__Flis.title: Senior Frontend Developer

Dominik__Roszkowski.name: Dominik Roszkowski
Dominik__Roszkowski.bio: Dominik is Google Developer Expert in Flutter eager to create beautiful apps for mobile and desktop. He's co-founder of Flutter Europe conference and active speaker on local meetups. You can find Flutter-related articles on his blog roszkowski.dev. He’s been working as a deputy manager of PW-Sat2 student satellite project.
Dominik__Roszkowski.shortBio: Dominik is Google Developer Expert in Flutter eager to create beautiful apps for mobile and desktop. He is active speaker on local meetups and writes Flutter-related articles on his blog roszkowski.dev.
Dominik__Roszkowski.title: Flutter Google Developer Expert

Peter__Tuszynski.name: Peter Tuszynski
Peter__Tuszynski.bio: Peter Tuszynski is a seasoned mobile software engineer based in Warsaw, Poland. He currently works as Chief Technology Officer at intent, a software company building digital products at the intersection of physical and digital worlds. He's been working with mobile apps since days of Symbian and PalmOS. Nowadays he focusses on iOS and Android with deep passion in machine learning and voice UIs. He's an ex-founder of a venture backed startup and ex-entrepreneur-in-residence at a leading VC fund, giving him unique perspective of both sides of the table.
Peter__Tuszynski.title: CTO

Nataliya__Pasichnyk.name: Nataliya Pasichnyk
Nataliya__Pasichnyk.bio: Nataliya is Engineering Manager at Codility, she has 5 years of experience working with Frontend technologies. Now she is leading a team of engineers, supporting their development and helping the team to deliver great features. She tries to combine coding and team management. Nataliya is Women Techmakers Ambassador and also a mentor in various programs which supports beginners in their path to IT.
Nataliya__Pasichnyk.shortBio: Nataliya is Engineering Manager at Codility, she has 5 years of experience working with Frontend technologies. Now she is leading a team of engineers, supporting their development and helping the team to deliver great features. She tries to combine coding and team management. Nataliya is Women Techmakers Ambassador and also a mentor in various programs which supports beginners in their path to IT.
Nataliya__Pasichnyk.title: Engineering Manager

Milosz__Moczkowski.name: Miłosz Moczkowski
Milosz__Moczkowski.bio: Miłosz is an accomplished coder and game developer. He picked programming at the age of 13 and it’s been his greatest passion ever since. Miłosz graduated from Polish-Japanese Institute of Information Technology. He has been developing Android apps since Froyo. One of his games was a crowdfunding hit that got featured in more than hundred countries. Apart from coding he enjoys everything science, engineering and sci-fi related.
Milosz__Moczkowski.shortBio: Android Developer Relations Engineer at Google
Milosz__Moczkowski.title: Android Developer Relations Engineer

Kateryna__Hrytsaienko.name: Kateryna Hrytsaienko
Kateryna__Hrytsaienko.bio: Kateryna Hrytsaienko is GDSC Mentor, WTM Ambassador, Java Consultant at Valtech and passionate Cloud and CI/CD Automation Enthusiast. "If we can make it simple, why then it still gets complex?" -- her moto for infrastructure solutions and life. Started as freelance full-stack developer, she tried her hand in JavaScript, TypeScript, GCP, Azure and even Common Lisp. Besides from work she runs as Google Student Club Mentor to help 4 wonderful Leads across Poland and Ukraine to evolve their clubs to bring impact to tech community. In addition she writes for #leadinsights rubric on Google Devs Europe Medium to share knowledge and vision for community development
Kateryna__Hrytsaienko.shortBio: Kateryna Hrytsaienko is GDSC Mentor, WTM Ambassador, Java Consultant at Valtech and passionate Cloud and CI/CD Automation Enthusiast. Besides from it, she writes #leadinsights rubric to share vision on developing tech community from scratch and runs as GDSC Mentor to help 4 wonderful Leads to evolve their clubs across Poland and Ukraine. "If we can make it simple, why then it still gets complex?" -- her moto for infrastructure solutions and life. Started as freelance full-stack developer, so she tried her hand in JavaScript, TypeScript, GCP, Azure and even Common Lisp. So she have plenty of stories to talk about
Kateryna__Hrytsaienko.title: Java Consultant at Valtech | Google GDSC Mentor | Women Techmakers Ambassador

Yonatan__Levin.name: Yonatan Levin
Yonatan__Levin.bio: Yonatan Levin is in love with tech and its application in the world. A startup person at heart, he spent his decade + career as a founder and at startups building products from 0 to 1. At monday.com, he built out the mobile team into the strong department it is today, and is a part of the Apps team, enabling developers worldwide to build applications on top of monday.com. Yonatan is also the founder of the largest Android community in the world "Android Academy" sharing the knowledge needed to become an Android developer.
Yonatan__Levin.shortBio: Startups person. Doer. Make things happening.  R&D Tech Lead @ http://monday.com Founder of Android Academy
Yonatan__Levin.title: R&D Tech Lead

Pawel__Manowiecki.name: Pawel Manowiecki
Pawel__Manowiecki.bio: Senior Enterprise Solutions Architect with 10+ years of experience in area of Business Intelligence and Data Warehousing. Leading projects and teams for various international customers and projects. Deep understanding of retail & consumer goods industries. Fascinated by Cloud and IoT trends.
Pawel__Manowiecki.shortBio: Senior Solutions Architect in areas of MongoDB, Cloud, IoT, Analytics.
Pawel__Manowiecki.title: Senior Solutions Architect

Michal__Tajchert.name: Michal Tajchert
Michal__Tajchert.bio: My adventure with mobile started with Windows Mobile PDAs ☎️ and quickly moved to Android development. 2 years in Software 🏠, 2 years doing startups and working for them, then 5 years in 💶 banking sector, currently in eCommerce 🛒. Since 2019 I'm working more on the management side of things and leading mobile teams. I like to stay on the verge of new stuff (Kotlin, Flutter, Compose, GraphQL - early enthusiast). In my spare time, I still love to code - ex. Kanarek app. I love to chat&work with people passionate about technology.
Michal__Tajchert.shortBio: Loves mobile, Engineering Manager @ eobuwie/MODIVO (eCommerce), ex-finance (PKO BP, BLIK, Raiffeisen), alumni of: SGH, PJATK and Ryerson DMZ. Author of kanarek.app
Michal__Tajchert.title: Engineering Manager

Rodolfo__Dias.name: Rodolfo Dias
Rodolfo__Dias.bio:
Team Leadership ❤️ JS ❤️ Open Source

Rodolfo has worked in a diverse pool of companies and research centers, in South America and Europe. He is Software Engineering Manager at Yara International and manages the software engineering teams of Yara's farming experience platform, with the goal of enabling regenerative agriculture and minimizing the climate impact of farming
Rodolfo__Dias.shortBio: Software Engineering Manager | Google Developer Expert
Rodolfo__Dias.title: Software Engineering Manager

Ewa__Gruszka.name: Ewa Gruszka
Ewa__Gruszka.title: Customer Engineer
Ewa__Gruszka.bio:
Ewa helps the largest enterprises in their digital transformation to the Google Cloud by adopting solutions in the areas of Data, Analytics and Machine Learning.

Previously, for many years associated with the Telecommunications sector, where she was responsible for broad customer analytics, as well as building and implementing Machine Learning models predicting user behaviour. Then, together with IBM Polska, she supported companies from many industries in the use and monetisation of knowledge hidden in data.
Ewa__Gruszka.shortBio: Ewa helps the largest enterprises in their digital transformation to the Google Cloud by adopting solutions in the areas of Data, Analytics and Machine Learning.

Michal__Zylinski.name: Michal Zylinski
Michal__Zylinski.title: Product Manager
Michal__Zylinski.bio: Michał works in Google as product manager responsible for Cloud Composer - Google Cloud’s data orchestration service. Previously he was leading a team of cloud architects, supporting Polish enterprise customers. His passion is data and its business and social impact.
Michal__Zylinski.shortBio: Michał works in Google as product manager responsible for Cloud Composer

Dilraj__Singh.name: Dilraj Singh
Dilraj__Singh.title: Principal Consultant
Dilraj__Singh.bio: Certified in various cloud technologies and Containerization environments and having badge of cloud agnostic tools
Dilraj__Singh.shortBio: 12 + Years of IT experience in Cloud and Development

Dariusz__Kalbarczyk.name: Dariusz Kalbarczyk
Dariusz__Kalbarczyk.title: Conference organiser NG Poland & JS Poland
Dariusz__Kalbarczyk.bio: Google Developer Expert, Developer Avocado 🥑, Angular lover, author, speaker, @ngPolandConf & @jsPolandConf conference organizer. Co-founder of the group Angular Warsaw and Angular Krakow. Skilled programmer with over 20 years of IT industry experience. Emerging technologies and social media enthusiast. He’s also spent years working closely with some of the biggest companies on the financial and telecommunication markets. While working with AngularJS/Angular for the past 7 years, he participated in the creation of a cutting edge banking transaction system designed for mobile platforms, and a group insurance support system, among others.
Dariusz__Kalbarczyk.shortBio: Google Developer Expert, Developer Avocado 🥑, Angular lover, author, speaker, @ngPolandConf & @jsPolandConf conference organizer.

Michal__Tuszynski.name: Michał Tuszyński
Michal__Tuszynski.title: Head of mobile
Michal__Tuszynski.bio: Michał is a mobile developer who specializes in building native iOS and Android apps. He started programming when the first iOS SDK came out. Throughout his career he worked with both big enterprises and small startups. Currently focusing on the intersection between physical and digital Intent, which boils down to IoT, wearables, automotive and similar businesses.
Michal__Tuszynski.shortBio: Mobile developer building on the intersection of physical and digital

Michal__Jablonski.name: Michał Jabłoński
Michal__Jablonski.title: Software Engineer
Michal__Jablonski.bio: Software Developer, GDG Warsaw Organizer, enrolled in a Master's Applied Computer Science program at Warsaw University of Technology
Michal__Jablonski.shortBio: Software Engineer + Geek + GDG Warsaw Organizer

Jarek__Potiuk.name: Jarek Potiuk
Jarek__Potiuk.title: Independent Open-Source contributor and advisor
Jarek__Potiuk.bio:
Independent Open-Source Contributor and Advisor, Committer and PMC member of Apache Airflow, Member of the Apache Software Foundation

Jarek is an Engineer with a broad experience in many subjects - Open-Source, Cloud, Mobile, Robotics, AI, Backend, Developer Experience, but he also had a lot of non-engineering experience - running a company, being CTO, organizing big, international community events, technical sales support, pr and marketing advisory but also looking at legal aspect of licensing and building open-source communities are all under his belt. 

With the experience in very small and very big companies and everything in-between, Jarek found his place in Open-Source world, where his internal individual-contributor drive can be used to the uttermost of the potential.
Jarek__Potiuk.shortBio: Independent Open-Source Contributor and Advisor, Committer and PMC member of Apache Airflow, Member of the Apache Software Foundation
